getArticleByFurl.title: The 100 Best Movies Of All Time

content.text: It’s a big question: what are the best movies of all time? And it’s one with many answers – there are all kinds of reasons why the greatest films ever made endure in the way they do. They create unforgettable images, conjure overwhelming emotions, craft thrilling stories, and deliver characters who leap off the screen. There’s astonishing technical mastery that brings those stories to life, plots that twist and turn in all kinds of unexpected ways, performances that help us fall head-over-heels for people who don’t exist, and transcendent experiences that change our heads and hearts. The best films – from classic movies that have stood the test of time, to contemporary works that changed the game – offer heartwarming comfort, iconic scares, big laughs, and pulse-pounding suspense, becoming firm audience favourites and garnering critical acclaim.

In creating a list of the 100 best movies of all time, _Empire_ asked readers to share their picks – a selection of movies that comfort, challenge, and pioneer. Films that blow your mind, help you see things from a new perspective, and that continue to shape cinema as we know it today. Films that make you _feel_ something. Combining reader votes with critics’ choices from Team Empire, here we have it – read it in full below.
Looking for our list of [The 100 Greatest TV Shows Of All Time? Read here](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/features/best-tv-shows-ever-2/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}.

coverImage.description:
[Quentin Tarantino](https://www.empireonline.com/people/quentin-tarantino/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s terrific twist on the heist-gone-wrong thriller ricochets the zing and fizz of its dialogue around a gloriously intense single setting (for the most part) and centres the majority of its action around one long and incredibly bloody death scene. Oh, and by the way: Nice Guy Eddie was shot by Mr. White. Who fired twice. Case closed.

  

[Read Empire's review of Reservoir Dogs](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/empire-essay-reservoir-dogs-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

images.description:
[Quentin Tarantino](https://www.empireonline.com/people/quentin-tarantino/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s terrific twist on the heist-gone-wrong thriller ricochets the zing and fizz of its dialogue around a gloriously intense single setting (for the most part) and centres the majority of its action around one long and incredibly bloody death scene. Oh, and by the way: Nice Guy Eddie was shot by Mr. White. Who fired twice. Case closed.

  

[Read Empire's review of Reservoir Dogs](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/empire-essay-reservoir-dogs-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[Bill Murray](https://www.empireonline.com/people/bill-murray/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} at the height of his loveable (eventually) schmuck powers. [Andie McDowell](https://www.empireonline.com/people/andie-macdowell/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} bringing the brains and the heart. And [Harold Ramis](https://www.empireonline.com/people/harold-ramis/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} (directing and co-writing with Danny Rubin) managing to find gold in the story of a man trapped in a time loop. It might not have been the first to tap this particular trope, but it's head and shoulders above the rest. Murray's snarktastic delivery makes the early going easy to laugh at, but as the movie finds deeper things to say about existence and morals, it never feels like a polemic.

  

[Read Empire's review of Groundhog Day](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/groundhog-day-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

When the first _Paddington_ was on the way, early trailers didn't look entirely promising. Yet co-writer/director [Paul King](https://www.empireonline.com/people/paul-king/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} delivered a truly wonderful film bursting with joy, imagination, kindness and just one or two hard stares. How was he going to follow that? Turns out, with more of the same, but also plenty of fresh pleasures. Paddington (bouncily voiced by [Ben Whishaw](https://www.empireonline.com/people/ben-whishaw/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}) matches wits with washed-up actor Phoenix Buchanan ([Hugh Grant](https://www.empireonline.com/people/hugh-grant/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, chewing scenery like fine steak), being framed for theft and getting sent to prison. Like all great sequels, it works superbly as a double bill with the original.

  

[Read Empire's review of Paddington 2](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/paddington-2-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[Jean-Pierre Jeunet](https://www.empireonline.com/people/jean-pierre-jeunet/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s beautifully whimsical Parisian rom-com succeeded not only because he found the perfect lead in [Audrey Tautou](https://www.empireonline.com/people/audrey-tautou/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, but also because his numerous surreal touches truly gave a sense that there is always magic in the world around us — if we only know how to look for it.

  

[Read Empire's review of Amelie](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/amelie-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[Ang Lee](https://www.empireonline.com/people/ang-lee/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} adapts Annie Proulx's short story (with [Larry McMurtry](https://www.empireonline.com/people/larry-mcmurtry/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} and [Diana Ossana](https://www.empireonline.com/people/diana-ossana/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} on script duty) with sensitivity, grace, and differing scope – the intimacy of the relationship between [Jake Gyllenhaal](https://www.empireonline.com/people/jake-gyllenhaal/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} and [Heath Ledger](https://www.empireonline.com/people/heath-ledger/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s shepherds backed by beautiful mountain landscapes. The love between Ennis Del Mar (Ledger) and Jack Twist (Gyllenhaal) is complicated by the mores of the time and their need to marry their respective girlfriends. It'll break your heart and offer hope all at the same time, and the film ended up scoring Best Adapted Screenplay, Music and Directing Oscars.

  

[Read Empire's review of Brokeback Mountain](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/brokeback-mountain-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[Richard Kelly](https://www.empireonline.com/people/richard-kelly/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s time-looping, sci-fi-horror-blending high-school movie is the very definition of a cult classic. It was a struggle to get made, it flopped on release, then found its crowd via word-of-mouth and a palpable sense that its creator really, you know, gets it. And let's not forget how goddamn funny it is, too.

  

[Read Empire's review of Donnie Darko](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/donnie-darko-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

With _Scott Pilgrim Vs. The World_, [Edgar Wright](https://www.empireonline.com/people/edgar-wright/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} leaned all the way in to the things that make his directorial style so singular – excellent needle drops, a bold colour palette, whip-pans and whip-smart wit alike. [Michael Cera](https://www.empireonline.com/people/michael-cera/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} is the put-upon protagonist, but it's Ramona's ([Mary Elizabeth Winstead](https://www.empireonline.com/people/mary-elizabeth-winstead/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}) seven deadly exes that set the screen alight, including [Chris Evans](https://www.empireonline.com/people/chris-evans/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} and [Brie Larson](https://www.empireonline.com/people/brie-larson/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} – before they were saving half the universe together. With masterful touches of magical realism and stunning shots that stick in the mind throughout, _Scott Pilgrim_ is one of Wright's most memorable.

  

[Read Empire's review of Scott Pilgrim](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/scott-pilgrim-vs-world-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

image.name: 93) Portrait Of A Lady On Fire

images.titleText: 93) Portrait Of A Lady On Fire
images.altText: Portrait Of A Lady On Fire
images.description:
[Celine Sciamma](https://www.empireonline.com/people/celine-sciamma/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s magnetic, masterful lesbian romance may be a recent addition to this list, but became an instant landmark of queer cinema upon its release. Starring [Noumie Merlant](https://www.empireonline.com/people/noemie-merlant/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} as an 18th century painter and [Aduele Haenel](https://www.empireonline.com/people/adele-haenel/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} as her elusive subject, _Portrait Of A Lady On Fire_ is a tale of an epic love developed in the quietest, most delicate way, formed in stolen moments and glances. Sciamma's carefully constructed script is matched by Claire Mathon's cinematography, each shot like a Renaissance painting brought to life. Pure poetry.

  

[Read Empire's review of Portrait Of A Lady On Fire](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/portrait-of-a-lady-on-fire/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

In some ways, [Luc Besson](https://www.empireonline.com/people/luc-besson/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s first English-language movie is a spiritual spin-off: after all, isn't [Jean Reno](https://www.empireonline.com/people/jean-reno/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s eponymous hitman just Nikita's Victor The Cleaner renamed and fleshed out? Of course, its greatest strength is in [Natalie Portman](https://www.empireonline.com/people/natalie-portman/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, delivering a luminous, career-creating performance as vengeful 12-year-old Mathilda, whose relationship with the monosyllabic killer is truly affecting, and nimbly stays just on the right side of acceptable.

  

[Read Empire's review of Léon](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/leon-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

If you're going to wrap up your tenure as one of the most loved superhero icons in fiction, it's hard to think of a better way than how [Hugh Jackman](https://www.empireonline.com/people/hugh-jackman/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} – with [James Mangold](https://www.empireonline.com/people/james-mangold/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} directing — punched out on the time clock of playing Wolverine. Set in a dark near-future world where an aging Logan is caring for a mentally unstable Professor Xavier ([Patrick Stewart](https://www.empireonline.com/people/patrick-stewart/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}) and getting mixed up yet again with some very dangerous people , _Logan_ is a truly original superhero tale that is mournful without being morbid. It's so outside the established mold, in fact, it's honestly a wonder the film ever got made.

  

[Read Empire's review of Logan](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/logan-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

It features time travel and a cyborg, with car chases and shoot-outs, but in [James Cameron](https://www.empireonline.com/people/james-cameron/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s first proper movie (ie. not featuring flying piranhas) it's all packed around the blood-covered endoskeleton of a relentless-killer horror pic. After all, what is [Arnold Schwarzenegger](https://www.empireonline.com/people/arnold-schwarzenegger/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s Uzi-9mm-toting Terminator, if not an upgraded version of _Halloween_'s Michael Myers?

  

[Read Empire's review of The Terminator](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/terminator-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

The Coen brothers' [Cormac McCarthy](https://www.empireonline.com/people/cormac-mccarthy/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} adaptation is a tension-ratcheting, 1980 Texas-set chase movie, which also thoughtfully considers the question: how can good people ever possibly deal with a world going to shit? It also revealed that [Javier Bardem](https://www.empireonline.com/people/javier-bardem/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} makes an awesome villain; ever since he played _No Country_'s cold-blooded assassin Anton Chigurh, Hollywood can't stop making him the bad guy.

  

[Read Empire's review of No Country For Old Men](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/country-old-men-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[James Cameron](https://www.empireonline.com/people/james-cameron/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} doesn't do things by halves. His movie about the 1912 sinking of the world's biggest cruise liner was the most expensive ever made, suffered a difficult, overrunning shoot, and was predicted to be a career-ending flop. But it turned out to be one of the most successful films of all time (in terms of both box office and Awards), and made him King Of The World.

  

[Read Empire's review of Titanic](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/titanic-2-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[William Friedkin](https://www.empireonline.com/people/william-friedkin/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s horror masterwork, in which a 12-year-old girl is possessed by a demon, has a reputation as a shocker (in the good sense), with the pea-soup vomit, head-spin and crucifix abuse moments the most regularly cited. But the reason it chills so deeply is the way it sustains and builds its disquieting atmosphere so craftily and consistently throughout.

  

[Read Empire's review of The Exorcist](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/exorcist-director-cut-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

After his standout introduction in _Captain America: Civil War_, 2018's _Black Panther_ allowed us to properly meet [Chadwick Boseman](https://www.empireonline.com/people/chadwick-boseman/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s T'Challa, and see his Wakandan kingdom in all its glory. Impeccably directed by _Creed_'s [Ryan Coogler](https://www.empireonline.com/people/ryan-coogler/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, it's an Afrofuturistic vision oozing with cool, colourful regality, expressed through its Oscar-winning costume design, stunning set pieces and thrumming soundtrack. Soaring to billion dollar-plus box office takings, Black Panther's cultural impact cannot be understated – and after the tragic loss of Boseman in 2020, the film lives on as the defining role for a truly remarkable talent.

  

[Read Empire's review of Black Panther](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/black-panther-review-2/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Before its release, you might have been forgiven for thinking it would be _Spaced: The Movie_. But [Edgar Wright](https://www.empireonline.com/people/edgar-wright/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, [Simon Pegg](https://www.empireonline.com/people/simon-pegg/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} and [Nick Frost](https://www.empireonline.com/people/nick-frost/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s first feature is genuinely stand-alone: a savvy blend of proper-funny comedy and seriously gruesome undead-horror which, funnily enough, played a big part in the zombie-movie resurgence we're still enjoying now.

  

[Read Empire's review of Shaun Of The Dead](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/shaun-dead-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[Sofia Coppola](https://www.empireonline.com/people/sofia-coppola/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s second film is the ultimate jet lag movie, locating its central almost-romance between listless college grad [Scarlett Johansson](https://www.empireonline.com/people/scarlett-johansson/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} and life-worn actor [Bill Murray](https://www.empireonline.com/people/bill-murray/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} amid the woozy, daydreamy bewilderment of being in a very foreign country and a very different time zone. And it's exactly right that we still don't know what he whispered to her at the end.

  

[Read Empire's review of Lost In Translation](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/lost-translation-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Marvel has cannily employed directors who have more usually made smaller, indie movies, handed them the keys to the giant machine that is their cinematic universe and (within reason) let them do their thing. Among the best to grasp that opportunity is [Taika Waititi](https://www.empireonline.com/people/taika-waititi/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, who helped find Thor's true funny bone, a more effective weapon than Mjolnir. _Ragnarok_, which shakes up Thor's entire world (by, er, destroying it) is a hilarious take on a superhero story, full of action, while re-introducing [Mark Ruffalo](https://www.empireonline.com/people/mark-ruffalo/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s Hulk in fantastic fashion and having us meet the likes of [Tessa Thompson'](https://www.empireonline.com/people/tessa-thompson/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}s Valkyrie and [Jeff Goldblum](https://www.empireonline.com/people/jeff-goldblum/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s Grandmaster.

  

[Read Empire's review of Thor: Ragnarok](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/thor-ragnarok-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

While the line-up team-up is a great concept, director [Bryan Singer](https://www.empireonline.com/people/bryan-singer/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} and writer [Christopher McQuarrie](https://www.empireonline.com/people/christopher-mcquarrie/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s super-twisted, uber-cool crime thriller attains true greatness through its supernatural-horror-style backdrop, conjuring a phantom menace "Keyser Soze" who terrifies even the most hardened criminal.

  

[Read Empire's review of The Usual Suspects](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/usual-suspects-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

The movie Universal originally didn't want [Hitchcock](https://www.empireonline.com/people/alfred-hitchcock/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} to make not only turned out to be a hands-down masterpiece but also effectively invented a genre: the psycho-killer slasher movie. No longer were movie monsters just big, hairy wolf-men, or vampires, or swampy fish-things. They could now look completely normal. They could be the guy sat right next to you, in fact...

  

[Read Empire's review of Psycho](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/psycho-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Twenty years on, and still nobody's made a better [James Ellroy](https://www.empireonline.com/people/james-ellroy/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} adaptation than [Curtis Hanson](https://www.empireonline.com/people/curtis-hanson/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} and [Brian Helgeland](https://www.empireonline.com/people/brian-helgeland/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s boldly streamlined take on the heavy-plotted third novel in Ellroy's 'L.A. Quartet'. Its spot-on casting hardly hurt, including [Russell Crowe](https://www.empireonline.com/people/russell-crowe/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} as conscience-discovering bruiser Bud White and [Guy Pearce](https://www.empireonline.com/people/guy-pearce/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} as ramrod rookie Ed Exley.

  

[Read Empire's review of L.A. Confidential](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/l-confidential-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

With the "Amblin" style so regularly referenced these days (most successfully in the Duffer brothers' _Stranger Things_), it's worth reminding ourselves that it was never more perfectly encapsulated than in _E.T_.: a children's adventure which carefully beds its supernatural elements in an utterly relatable everykid world, and tempers its cuter, more sentimental moments with a true sense of jeopardy.

  

[Read Empire's review of E.T.](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/et-extra-terrestrial-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Years before battling Shang-Chi in the MCU, Hong Kong acting legend [Tony Leung](https://www.empireonline.com/people/tony-leung/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} was director [Wong Kar-wai](https://www.empireonline.com/people/wong-kar-wai/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s greatest muse in gorgeous, simmering masterpieces like _Chungking Express_, _Happy Together_ — and this remarkable romance, perhaps their greatest collaboration. Leung plays a journalist renting an apartment in 1960s Hong Kong; his neighbour, played by Maggie Cheung, appears as lonely and lost as he is. It soon emerges their spouses are having an affair, and a romance of stolen glances and intimate longing begins to emerge. Love stories are rarely as ravishingly beautiful (or deeply influential) as this.

  

[Read Empire's review of In The Mood For Love](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/mood-love-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

image.name: 77) Star Wars: Return Of The Jedi

images.titleText: 77) Star Wars: Return Of The Jedi
images.altText: Star Wars: Return Of The Jedi
images.description:
In this post-_Phantom Menace_ world, the Ewoks don't seem quite so egregious, do they? Endor's teddy-bear guerillas might have got sneered at, but they shouldn't blind us to Jedi's assets: the explosive team-re-gathering opening; the crazily high-speed forest chase; and that marvellously edited three-way climactic battle that dextrously flipped us between lightsabers, spaceships and a ferocious (albeit fuzzy) forest conflict.

  

[Read Empire's review of Return Of The Jedi](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/star-wars-episode-vi-return-jedi-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[Denis Villeneuve](https://www.empireonline.com/people/denis-villeneuve/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s empathic, perception-bending alien visitation drama is a delicately crafted modern rework of _The Day The Earth Stood Still_, except the extra-terrestrials are truly otherworldly and there's the sky-high obstacle that is the language barrier. With its message that open-minded communication enables us to realise the things we have in common with those who appear vastly different, it feels like genuinely compulsive viewing for these troubled times.

  

[Read Empire's review of Arrival](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/arrival-2-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Take a simple concept (don't make a sound, or aliens will get you), a stellar cast ([Emily Blunt](https://www.empireonline.com/people/emily-blunt/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, Millicent Simmonds, Noah Jupe) and a director with a laser-sharp vision ([John Krasinski](https://www.empireonline.com/people/john-krasinski/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}) and what do you get? As it turns out, one of the most innovative, refreshing, unbearably tense horror movies of the 21st century. From the second it starts, the imposed silence of _A Quiet Place_ makes it a revelatory cinematic experience – as the Abbott family pad gently around their home, the store, the woods, you feel in your bones that one wrong step equals disaster. The (loudly) ticking time bomb of imminent childbirth sets the scene for a stellar scary finale, but it's the deeply endearing family dynamic that sets this apart.

  

[Read Empire's review of A Quiet Place](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/quiet-place-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

For their follow up to the superb _Shallow Grave_, [Danny Boyle](https://www.empireonline.com/people/danny-boyle/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} (director), [Andrew Macdonald](https://www.empireonline.com/people/andrew-macdonald/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} (producer) and [John Hodge](https://www.empireonline.com/people/john-hodge/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} (screenwriter) foolhardily elected to film the supposedly unfilmable: [Irvine Welsh](https://www.empireonline.com/people/irvine-welsh/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s scrappy, episodic, multi-perspective novel about Edinburgh low-lives. The result couldn't have been more triumphant: the cinematic incarnation of 'Cool Britannia' came with a kick-ass soundtrack, and despite some dark subject matter, came with a punch-the-air uplifting pay-off.

  

[Read Empire's review of Trainspotting](http://empireonline.com/movies/reviews/trainspotting-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[David Lynch](https://www.empireonline.com/people/david-lynch/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} messes with Hollywood itself in a mystery tale that's as twisted as the road it's named after, while presenting Tinseltown as both Dream Factory and a realm of Nightmares. It also put [Naomi Watts](https://www.empireonline.com/people/naomi-watts/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} on the map; her audition scene remains as stunning as it was 20 years ago.

  

[Read Empire's review of Mulholland Drive](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/mulholland-drive-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Photographer LB Jeffries ([James Stewart](https://www.empireonline.com/people/james-stewart/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}) is on sick leave, with a broken leg. He's bored to tears, so he starts spying on his neighbours. Then he witnesses a murder. OR DOES HE? [Alfred Hitchcock](https://www.empireonline.com/people/alfred-hitchcock/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} really knew how to take a corker of a premise and spin it into a peerless thriller (that's why they called him The Master Of Suspense), but _Rear Window_ also deserves praise for an astonishing set build: that entire Greenwich Village courtyard was constructed at Paramount Studios, complete with a drainage system that could handle all the rain.

  

[Read Empire's review of Rear Window](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/rear-window-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

A lot has been said about the opening to [Pete Docter](https://www.empireonline.com/people/pete-docter/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s Pixar masterpiece, and rightly so, wringing tears from the hardest of hearts with a wordless sequence set to [Michael Giacchino](https://www.empireonline.com/people/michael-giacchino/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s lovely, Oscar-winning score that charts the ups and downs of a couple's marriage. Yet while the majority of the film is more of a straight-ahead adventure tale (albeit one with a wacky bird and talking dogs), that doesn't make it any less satisfying. And let's be honest — the story of a man who uses balloons to float his house to a foreign land, accidentally picking up a young wilderness explorer scout as he does, feels perfectly Pixar.

  

[Read Empire's review of Up](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/movie-2-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Having [Phil Lord](https://www.empireonline.com/people/phil-lord/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} and [Chris Miller](https://www.empireonline.com/people/chris-miller/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s names on a movie is regularly the guarantee of something great, but the full team behind this animated marvel (in both upper- and lower-case senses of the word) is what makes it work. [Bob Persichetti](https://www.empireonline.com/people/bob-persichetti/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, [Peter Ramsey](https://www.empireonline.com/people/peter-ramsey/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, and [Rodney Rothman](https://www.empireonline.com/people/rodney-rothman/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} all added something as directors (with Rothman co-writing alongside Lord) and their animators whipped up a visually dynamic, exciting, and heartwarming adventure that literally spans multiverses before the MCU introduced it. Bringing Miles Morales to the screen was a masterstroke, and [Shameik Moore](http:///people/shameik-moore/)'s vocal work gives him buckets of charm.

  

[Read Empire's review of Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/spider-man-spider-verse-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

From its Sergio Leone-riffing opening to its insanely OTT, history-rewriting finale, [Tarantino'](https://www.empireonline.com/people/quentin-tarantino/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}s World War II caper never once fails to surprise and entertain. As ever, though, QT's at his best in claustrophobic situations, with the tavern scene ramping up the tension to almost unbearable levels.

  

[Read Empire's review of Inglourious Basterds](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/inglourious-basterds-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

With her directorial debut, the wry wit and emotional potency of [Greta Gerwig](https://www.empireonline.com/people/greta-gerwig/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s previous work came even sharper into focus – telling a beautifully nuanced coming-of-age story about mothers, daughters, and the hometowns you yearn to leave, only for them to be truly appreciated in the rear-view mirror. [Saoirse Ronan](https://www.empireonline.com/people/saoirse-ronan/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} is perfectly precocious as the not-always-likeable Christine 'Lady Bird' McPherson, experiencing fractured friendships, first fuckboys, and fateful fumbles in her final year of high school in 2003 Sacramento.

  

[Read Empire's review of Lady Bird](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/lady-bird-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

A joyous, vibrant Technicolor celebration of the movies, that's such an essential viewing experience there should perhaps be a law that it feature in every DVD and Blu-ray collection. It's no mere Hollywood self-love exercise, though. As star Don Lockwood, [Gene Kelly](https://www.empireonline.com/people/gene-kelly/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} brings a sense of exasperation at the film industry's diva-indulging daftness, making it a gentle piss-take, too.

  

[Read Empire's review of Singin' In The Rain](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/singin-rain-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

image.name: 66) One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest

images.titleText: 66) One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest
images.altText: One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest
images.description:
Ken Kesey's era-defining novel was in good hands with screenwriters Lawrence Hauben and Bo Goldman, not to mention director [Milos Forman](https://www.empireonline.com/people/milos-forman/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}: five Oscars were testament to that, including one for [Jack Nicholson](https://www.empireonline.com/people/jack-nicholson/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, who's arguably never been better as a man destined to be chewed up by the unfeeling system (ditto [Louise Fletcher](https://www.empireonline.com/people/louise-fletcher/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, who represents that system in the form of Nurse Ratched).

  

[Read Empire's review of One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/one-flew-cuckoo-nest-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

A film so good they remade it twice — as _The Magnificent Seven_, then as _Battle Beyond The Stars_. Or four times, arguably... if you count _A Bug's Life_ and the remake of _The Magnificent Seven_. You could also make the case that _Avengers Assemble_ is a version, too. The point is this: [Akira Kurosawa](https://www.empireonline.com/people/akira-kurosawa/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s epic, 16th century-set drama about a motley gang of warriors uniting to save a village from bandits couldn't be more influential. Cinema simply wouldn't be the same without it.

  

[Read Empire's review of Seven Samurai](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/seven-samurai-review/)

As much a technical marvel as it is an acting tour-de-force, [Damien Chazelle](https://www.empireonline.com/people/damien-chazelle/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s Los Angeles love letter proved a ridiculously easy movie to fall in love with, even for those who may have grumbled that they weren't really into musicals before sitting down to watch it. Go on, admit it: You're still humming "Another Day Of Sun", aren't you?

  

[Read Empire's review of La La Land](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/la-la-land-review-2/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Even given the darker tones of a few Key And Peele sketches, no one could have predicted that [Jordan Peele](https://www.empireonline.com/people/jordan-peele/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} would place himself on track to become a modern master of horror. And it all started with this, the Oscar-winning kick-off to his film career in which [Daniel Kaluuya](https://www.empireonline.com/people/daniel-kaluuya/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s Chris meets his girlfriend Rose's ([Allison Williams](https://www.empireonline.com/people/allison-williams/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}) parents and discovers some truly shocking secrets. White guilt, specific racism, slavery and more blend into a socially conscious terror tale that rings every note with pitch-perfect accuracy. You'll never look at a cup of tea the same way again.

  

[Read Empire's review of Get Out](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/get-2-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

If you only ever see one [David Lean](https://www.empireonline.com/people/david-lean/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} movie... well, don't. Watch as many as you can. But if you really insist on only seeing one [David Lean](https://www.empireonline.com/people/peter-otoole/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} movie, then make sure it's _Lawrence Of Arabia_, the movie that put both the "sweeping" and the "epic" into "sweeping epic" with its breath-taking depiction of T.E. Lawrence's ([Peter O'Toole](https://www.empireonline.com/people/peter-otoole/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}) Arab-uniting efforts against the German-allied Turks during World War I. It's a different world to the one we're in now, of course, but Lean's mastery of expansive storytelling does much to smooth out any elements (such as [Alec Guinness](https://www.empireonline.com/people/alec-guinness/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} playing an Arab) that may rankle modern sensibilities.

  

[Read Empire's review of Lawrence Of Arabia](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/lawrence-arabia-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[Guillermo Del Toro](https://www.empireonline.com/people/guillermo-del-toro/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s fairy tale for grown-ups, as pull-no-punches brutal as it is gorgeously, baroquely fantastical. There's an earthy, primal feel to his fairy-world here, alien and threatening rather than gasp-inducing and 'magical', thanks in no small part to the truly cheese-dream nightmarish demon-things Del Toro conjures up, sans CGI, with the assistance of performer [Doug Jones](https://www.empireonline.com/people/doug-jones/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}.

  

[Read Empire's review of Pan's Labyrinth](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/pan-labyrinth-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[Edgar Wright](https://www.empireonline.com/people/edgar-wright/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, [Simon Pegg](https://www.empireonline.com/people/simon-pegg/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} and [Nick Frost](https://www.empireonline.com/people/nick-frost/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s tribute to big American cop movies isn't just a great fish-out-of-water comedy, sending high-achieving London policeman Nick Angel (Pegg) to the most boring place in the UK (or so it seems). It also manages to wring every last drip of funny out of executing spot-on bombastic, Bayhem-style action in a sleepy English small-town setting.

  

[Read Empire's review of Hot Fuzz](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/hot-fuzz-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Adapted from Tarell Alvin's play _In Moonlight, Black Boys Look Blue_, [Barry Jenkins](https://www.empireonline.com/people/barry-jenkins/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}' Oscar-winning drama is the kind of film that seeps under your skin and stays there. Tracking one man's life in three stages, and the love (and lack of it) that made him who he is, _Moonlight_ evokes a sense of intimacy so palpable, the camera's gaze into the characters' eyes so intense, you can't bear to look away. [Mahershala Ali](https://www.empireonline.com/people/naomie-harris/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} and [Naomie Harris](https://www.empireonline.com/people/naomie-harris/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} are impeccable in supporting roles, with [Trevante Rhodes](https://www.empireonline.com/people/trevante-rhodes/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} and [Andre Holland](https://www.empireonline.com/people/andre-holland/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} delivering an unforgettable final act.

  

[Read Empire's review of Moonlight.](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/moonlight-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Marvel took one of its biggest swings with this space-borne adventure, which featured the MCU's freakiest and least-known characters (a talking raccoon, a walking tree, a green assassin lady, a muscleman named after a Bond villain and Star-who!?), starred that schlubby fellah from _Parks And Rec_, and was directed by the guy who turned [Michael Rooker](https://www.empireonline.com/people/michael-rooker/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} into a giant slug-monster in _Slither_. Which is pretty cool, when you think about it.

  

[Read Empire's review of Guardians Of The Galaxy](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/guardians-galaxy-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Putting together the director of _Arrival_ with a sci-fi franchise that – for box office performance reasons — hasn't been overexploited the way some others have, seemed like a no-brainer. It's actually a big brainer, with [Denis Villeneuve](https://www.empireonline.com/people/denis-villeneuve/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} dipping into [Philip K. Dick'](https://www.empireonline.com/people/philip-k-dick/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}s universe and constructing a sequel that not only doesn't embarrass [Ridley Scott](https://www.empireonline.com/people/ridley-scott/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s original, but builds out that world, adding layers and texture while still feeling of a piece. Audiences still didn't exactly bite, but between [Harrison Ford](https://www.empireonline.com/people/harrison-ford/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} revisiting his iconic replicant hunter and [Ryan Gosling](https://www.empireonline.com/people/ryan-gosling/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} grappling with his own identity, _2049_ is a triumph of quiet character moments and glorious, sense-enveloping spectacle.

  

[Read Empire's review of Blade Runner 2049](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/blade-runner-2049-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Or, I'm Gonna Git You Zuckerberg. Portrayed as an über-ruthless ultra-nerd by [Jesse Eisenberg](https://www.empireonline.com/people/jesse-eisenberg/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, it's fair to say the Facebook founder came out of [David Fincher](https://www.empireonline.com/people/david-fincher/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s social-media drama smelling less of roses than the stuff you grow them in. But it is great drama, expertly wrought by screenwriter [Aaron Sorkin](https://www.empireonline.com/people/aaron-sorkin/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, who exploits the story's central paradox (a guy who doesn't get people makes a fortune getting people together online) to supremely juicy effect.

  

[Read Empire's review of The Social Network](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/social-network-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[Martin Scorsese](https://www.empireonline.com/people/martin-scorsese/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} and [Paul Schrader](https://www.empireonline.com/people/paul-schrader/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s gripping portrayal of a mentally crumbling Vietnam vet ([Robert De Niro](https://www.empireonline.com/people/robert-de-niro/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s Travis Bickle) who ultimately figures the only way to wash the crime-caked streets of New York is with a nice, big bloodbath. Everyone here's at the top of their game: Scorsese, Schrader, De Niro, 14-year-old [Jodie Foster](https://www.empireonline.com/people/jodie-foster/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} and composer [Bernard Herrmann](https://www.empireonline.com/people/bernard-herrmann/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}. Yes, it's still talkin' to us.

  

[Read Empire's review of Taxi Driver](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/taxi-driver-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

The sheer bludgeoning, blood-spilling, visceral power of its Omaha Beach, D-Day-landing opening act ensured that [Steven Spielberg](https://www.empireonline.com/people/steven-spielberg/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s fourth World War II movie set the standard for all future battle depictions. Its shaky-staccato-desaturated style (courtesy of [Janusz Kaminski](https://www.empireonline.com/people/janusz-kaminski/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s ingenious cinematography) newsreel made cinema has been oft-copied, but rarely bettered.

  

[Read Empire's review of Saving Private Ryan](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/saving-private-ryan-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[Robert Zemeckis](https://www.empireonline.com/people/robert-zemeckis/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}' affable stroll through some of America's most turbulent decades, as seen through the childlike eyes of the simple-but-successful Forrest — the role which earned [Tom Hanks](https://www.empireonline.com/people/tom-hanks/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} his second Oscar in two years. And it says a lot about the film's emotional heft that it managed to win an Oscar itself, when it was in competition with both _Pulp Fiction_ and _The Shawshank Redemption_.

  

[Read Empire's review of Forrest Gump](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/forrest-gump-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

"Ever fired your gun in the air and gone 'Ahhhh?'" PC Danny Butterman's well-placed reference in _Hot Fuzz_ confirmed, if confirmation were ever needed, that _Point Break_ is a fundamental pillar of '90s pop culture cool, and one of the most memorable action blockbusters ever made. In [Keanu Reeves](https://www.empireonline.com/people/keanu-reeves/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} and [Patrick Swayze](https://www.empireonline.com/people/patrick-swayze/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, we get two smouldering sides of the same anti-heroic coin; in W. Peter Iliff's screenplay, we get gems of dialogue like "The correct term is 'babes', sir"; and in [Kathryn Bigelow](https://www.empireonline.com/people/kathryn-bigelow/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s frenetic, confident direction, we get intense foot chases, fiery shoot-outs, epic surfing, and a spot of light skydiving. It shouldn't work: extreme sports, bank robberies _and_ male bonding? But it does, every time.

  

[Read Empire's review of Point Break](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/point-break-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

If [Damien Chazelle](https://www.empireonline.com/people/damien-chazelle/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s semi-autobiographical drama taught us anything, it's that jazz drumming is more hazardous to learn than base jumping. Especially when your mentor is [J.K. Simmons](https://www.empireonline.com/people/jk-simmons/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}' monstrous Fletcher: a raging bully who makes army drill instructors look like Care Bears. Though, of course, you could always argue that Fletcher's methods certainly got great results out of [Miles Teller](https://www.empireonline.com/people/miles-teller/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s battered but triumphant Andrew...

  

[Read Empire's review of Whiplash](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/whiplash-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

If _Psycho_ was [Hitchcock](https://www.empireonline.com/people/alfred-hitchcock/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s big shocker, then _Vertigo_ is the one that gets properly under your skin. With [James Stewart](https://www.empireonline.com/people/james-stewart/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s detective stalking Kim Novak's mysterious woman, witnessing her suicide, then becoming obsessed with her double, it's certainly disturbing and most definitely (as the title suggests) disorientating. In the most artful and inventive way.

  

[Read Empire's review of Vertigo](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/vertigo-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

For a Western world raised on Disney movies, _Spirited Away_ was a bracing change of pace – pure, uncut Studio Ghibli. Taking in bathhouses, spirits of Shinto folklore, and morality without clear-cut distinctions of good and evil, [Hayao Miyazaki](https://www.empireonline.com/people/hayao-miyazaki/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s major crossover hit is distinctly Japanese. It's the film that brought Studio Ghibli – and anime at large – to mainstream Western audiences, an influence increasingly felt in the likes of _Moana_ and _Frozen II_.

  

[Read Empire's review of Spirited Away](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/spirited-away-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

As high-concept comedies go, _Ghostbusters_ is positively stratospheric: a story of demonic incursion... with gags! And it manages to wring a fantastic supernatural adventure out of that concept, while never neglecting the opportunity to deliver a great laugh; or, on the flipside, ever allowing the zaniness to swallow up plot coherence. Ray Parker Jr was right. Bustin' did indeed make us feel good.

  

[Read Empire's review of Ghostbusters](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/ghostbusters-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[Spike Lee](https://www.empireonline.com/people/spike-lee/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} had already caused a stir with his first two films – _She's Gotta Have It_ and _School Daze_ – but this was the one that changed everything, with Lee at full pelt, fully formed, in full command and full of fury. Over the longest, hottest summer's day in Brooklyn's Bed-Stuy, already boiling tensions between the African-Americans on the block and the Italian-Americans running a pizzeria eventually peak, erupting into violence. It's an absolutely flawless, funny, frightening piece of work, rammed with soon-to-be iconography from start to finish. It hasn't dated a day.

  

[Read Empire's review of Do The Right Thing](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/right-thing-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Spielberg's masterpiece, hands down. You might say the shark looks fakey in Jaws. You may wonder how Indy clung to the German sub in Raiders. But there's no flaws to be found in his harrowing, (mostly) monochromatic depiction of Nazi persecution of the Jewish community in Krakow. Unless you're the kind of shallow person who only watches movies that are 'entertaining'. In which case, you're missing out.

  

[Read Empire's review of Schindler's List](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/schindler-list-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

You've got to hand it to the Coen brothers. Not only did they make arguably the funniest movie of the '90s — which has since spawned a genuine film cult — they also managed to construct a kidnap mystery in which the detective isn't a detective and nobody was actually kidnapped. With bowling, marmots and a urine-stained rug.

  

[Read Empire's review of The Big Lebowski](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/big-lebowski-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Frank Capra's Christmas fantasy was the movie that coaxed a war-battered [James Stewart](https://www.empireonline.com/people/james-stewart/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} back to acting, and a good thing, too: as George Bailey, who's shown a mind-blowing parallel reality in which he never existed, Stewart was never more appealing. And he tempers any potential schmaltz, too, with a sense of underlying world-weariness — one that he no doubt brought back from the conflict in Europe.

  

[Read Empire's review of It's A Wonderful Life](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/wonderful-life-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

If America were a person, then oil man Daniel Plainview ([Daniel Day-Lewis](https://www.empireonline.com/people/daniel-day-lewis/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}) is a vampire. (A milkshake-drinking vampire, if you feel like mixing our metaphor with his own.) Which is why it's appropriate that [Paul Thomas Anderson](https://www.empireonline.com/people/paul-thomas-anderson/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} gives the film a bit of a horror-movie vibe throughout and Day-Lewis delivers such a deliciously monstrous performance... right up to the point where he spills literal blood in an empty mansion, haunted only by himself.

  

[Read Empire's review of There Will Be Blood](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/will-blood-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Juries most often amount to little more than set dressing in courtroom dramas. But [Sidney Lumet](https://www.empireonline.com/people/sidney-lumet/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s film finds all its drama outside the courtroom itself and inside a jury deliberation room packed with fantastic character actors, who are forced to re-examine a seemingly straightforward case by lone-voice juror Henry Fonda. It's all about the value of looking at things differently, and a reminder that nothing is more important than great dialogue.

  

[Read Empire's review of 12 Angry Men](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/twelve-angry-men-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Not only the first horror to win a Best Picture Oscar, it's also only the third movie to score in all four main categories: Picture, Director (the late, great [Jonathan Demme](https://www.empireonline.com/people/jonathan-demme/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}), Actress ([Jodie Foster](https://www.empireonline.com/people/jodie-foster/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}) and Actor ([Anthony Hopkins](https://www.empireonline.com/people/anthony-hopkins/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}) — the latter managing that despite technically being a supporting performer, with a mere 25-ish minutes of screen time. Even so, it feels like Foster's movie more than anybody's: her vulnerable-but-steely Clarice Starling is defined by her ability, not her gender.

  

[Read Empire's review of The Silence Of The Lambs](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/silence-lambs-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[Orson Welles](https://www.empireonline.com/people/orson-welles/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}' game-changing fictional biopic, that managed to both launch his film career and ruin it at the same time (turns out it's not a good idea to piss off powerful newspaper magnates by viciously satirising them to a mass audience). Not only did he use impressive new film-making techniques that make it feel like a movie far younger than its 76 years, but its power-corrupts story still resonates loudly. Now more than ever, in fact.

  

[Read Empire's review of Citizen Kane](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/citizen-kane-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[Ridley Scott](https://www.empireonline.com/people/ridley-scott/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s comeback (after a bad run with 1492, White Squall and G.I. Jane). [Russell Crowe'](https://www.empireonline.com/people/russell-crowe/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}s big Hollywood breakthrough. And, thanks to the scope of Scott's visual ambition combined with a leap forward in CGI quality, the movie that showed the industry you could make colossal historical epics commercially viable once more. Yes, we were entertained.

  

[Read Empire's review of Gladiator](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/gladiator-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

image.name: 38) The Good, The Bad And The Ugly
image.fileName: 38 the good the bad and the ugly.jpg

images.titleText: 38) The Good, The Bad And The Ugly
images.altText: The Good, The Bad And The Ugly
images.description:
Sergio Leone sets three renegades against each other in a treasure hunt backdropped against the chaos and madness of the American Civil War. The result is the movie on his CV which best balances art and entertainment. [Clint Eastwood](https://www.empireonline.com/people/clint-eastwood/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} and Lee Van Cleef are great value as Blondie and Angel Eyes, but it's Eli Wallach's Tuco who steals this Wild West show: "When you have to shoot, shoot. Don't talk."

  

[Read Empire's review of The Good, The Bad And The Ugly](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/good-bad-ugly-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Aka [David Fincher](https://www.empireonline.com/people/david-fincher/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s second debut movie. What sounded like a daft, novelty serial-killer thriller turned out to be a deeply rattling proper-shocker, which had the guts to throw down its biggest narrative twist halfway through, as warped murderer-moralist John Doe gives himself up. A twist made all the more effective thanks to [Kevin Spacey](https://www.empireonline.com/people/kevin-spacey/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s insistence he wasn't billed until the end credits.

  

[Read Empire's review of Seven](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/seven-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

image.name: 36) Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind

images.titleText: 36) Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind
images.altText: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind
images.description:
Director [Michel Gondry](https://www.empireonline.com/people/michel-gondry/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} and screenwriter [Charlie Kaufman](https://www.empireonline.com/people/charlie-kaufman/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} deconstruct the relationship drama via a fantastic psycho-sci-fi device, as [Jim Carrey](https://www.empireonline.com/people/jim-carrey/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s Joel races through his own mind to reverse a process by which all his memories of his failed relationship with [Kate Winslet](https://www.empireonline.com/people/kate-winslet/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s Clementine are to be erased. Which is a brilliantly weird, round-the-houses way of reminding us that heartbreak should be valued as one of the things that makes us. Better to have loved and lost, and all that.

  

[Read Empire's review of Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/eternal-sunshine-spotless-mind-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[Stanley Kubrick](https://www.empireonline.com/people/stanley-kubrick/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s elegant adaptation of [Stephen King](https://www.empireonline.com/people/stephen-king/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s haunted-hotel story, starring a wonderfully deranged [Jack Nicholso](https://www.empireonline.com/people/jack-nicholson/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}n, is often cited as The Scariest Horror Movie Ever Made (perhaps tied with _The Exorcist_), but it's also the Least Suitable Movie To Watch On Father's Day Ever. Unless you're the kind of Dad who thinks obsessively typing the same sentence over and over then chasing after your wife and kid with an axe constitutes good parenting.

  

[Read Empire's review of The Shining](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/shining-2-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

image.name: 34) The Lord Of The Rings: The Two Towers

images.titleText: 34) The Lord Of The Rings: The Two Towers
images.altText: The Lord Of The Rings: The Two Towers
images.description:
Aside from Boromir, Aragorn and the small-town denizens of Bree, there's not a huge amount of human representation in _The Fellowship Of The Ring_. So one of the pleasures of _The Two Towers_ is seeing Middle-earth truly open out after the arrival at Rohan, where the series takes on more of a sweeping, Nordic feel... Building up, of course, to Helm's Deep, a ferocious action crescendo which features gratuitous scenes of dwarf-tossing.

  

[Read Empire's review of The Two Towers](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/lord-rings-two-towers-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

When you've got such a clear-cut good-vs-evil scenario as World War II, it takes guts to put out a film which lets its (anti-) hero lurk for so long in a grey area of that conflict — while said War was still raging, no less. Of course, Rick ([Humphrey Bogart](https://www.empireonline.com/people/humphrey-bogart/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}) eventually does the right thing, but watching him make both the Resistance and the Nazis squirm right up to the final scene is truly joyous.

  

[Read Empire's review of Casablanca](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/casablanca-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Any argument about whether or not modern remakes can ever be better than the 'classic' originals should be ended pretty quickly by mentioning this movie. With the help of SFX genius [Rob Bottin](https://www.empireonline.com/people/rob-bottin/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, [John Carpenter](https://www.empireonline.com/people/john-carpenter/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} took the bones of [Howard Hawks](https://www.empireonline.com/people/howard-hawks/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}' 1951 _The Thing From Another World_ and crafted an intense, frosty sci-fi thriller featuring Hollywood's ultimate movie monster: one that could be any of us at any time, before contorting into a genuine biological nightmare.

  

[Read Empire's review of The Thing](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/thing-2-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[Christopher Nolan](https://www.empireonline.com/people/christopher-nolan/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s tribute to _2001_ and _The Right Stuff_ (with a little added _The Black Hole_) presents long-distance space travel as realistically as it's possible to with the theoretical physics currently available. From the effects of gravity to the emotional implication of time dilation, it mixes science and sentiment to great effect. And it has a sarcastic robot, too.

  

[Read Empire's review of Interstellar](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/interstellar-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[Michael Mann](https://www.empireonline.com/people/michael-mann/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s starry upgrade of his TV movie _LA Takedown_ squeezed every last drop of icon-juice out of its heavyweight double-billing, bringing [Pacino](https://www.empireonline.com/people/al-pacino/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} and [De Niro](https://www.empireonline.com/people/robert-de-niro/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} together on screen, sharing scenes for the very first time. The trick was to only do it twice during the entire running time, with that first diner meeting virtually fizzing with alpha-star electricity.

  

[Read Empire's review of Heat](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/heat-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

The film-maker go-to movie du jour. [Gareth Edwards](https://www.empireonline.com/people/gareth-edwards/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} cited [Coppola](https://www.empireonline.com/people/francis-ford-coppola/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s vivid and visceral jungle trek as a major influence on _Rogue One_; [Jordan Vogt-Roberts](https://www.empireonline.com/people/jordan-vogt-roberts/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} drew from it extensively for _Kong: Skull Island_, and [Matt Reeves](https://www.empireonline.com/people/matt-reeves/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} sees _War For The Planet Of The Apes_ as his own simian-related tribute. Hardly surprising; it's both a visually rich war movie and also a powerfully resonant journey into the darkest recesses of the human soul.

  

[Read Empire's review of Apocalypse Now](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/apocalypse-now-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

image.name: 28) Indiana Jones And The Last Crusade

images.titleText: 28) Indiana Jones And The Last Crusade
images.altText: Indiana Jones And The Last Crusade
images.description:
You voted... wisely. There may only be 12 years' difference between [Harrison Ford](https://www.empireonline.com/people/harrison-ford/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} and [Sean Connery](https://www.empireonline.com/people/sean-connery/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, but it's hard to imagine two better actors to play a bickering father and son, off on a globetrotting, Nazi-bashing, mythical mystery tour. After all, you've got [Spielberg](https://www.empireonline.com/people/steven-spielberg/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}/[Lucas](https://www.empireonline.com/people/george-lucas/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}' own version of James Bond... And the original Bond himself.

  

[Read Empire's review of Indiana Jones And The Last Crusade](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/indiana-jones-last-crusade-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

image.name: 27) The Lord Of The Rings The Return Of The King

images.titleText: 27) The Lord Of The Rings The Return Of The King
images.altText: The Lord Of The Rings The Return Of The King
images.description:
Anyone who bangs on about all those endings is missing the many joys of [Peter Jackson](https://www.empireonline.com/people/peter-jackson/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s Academy Award-laden trilogy-closer. It has some of the most colossal and entertaining battle scenes ever mounted; it has an awesome giant spider; it has that fantastic dramatic-ironic twist when Gollum saves the day through his own treachery; and it has that bit where Eowyn says, "I am no man". Deserves. Every. Oscar.

  

[Read Empire's review of The Return Of The King](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/lord-rings-return-king-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

One man using only his wits and whatever he can extract from his environment. A gang of bad guys terrorising the locals. If Die Hard wasn't set in a skyscraper during the 1980s, it could easily be a Western. A Western which, in the form of [Bruce Willis](https://www.empireonline.com/people/bruce-willis/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, not only convinced the world a TV-comedy star could be an action-hero, but also gave us one of our most seethingly charismatic big-screen villain-players: [Alan Rickman](https://www.empireonline.com/people/alan-rickman/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}.

  

[Read Empire's review of Die Hard](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/die-hard-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

After all the pre-release hype about how dark and brutal _Fight Club_ was, one of the most surprising things to discover on seeing it was just how funny it actually was. And just as well; if you weren't laughing at Bob's "bitch-tits" or Tyler Durden's human-fat soap-making antics, it would be pretty hard to process [David Fincher](https://www.empireonline.com/people/david-fincher/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s bravura take on [Chuck Palahniuk](https://www.empireonline.com/people/chuck-palahniuk/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s tale of modern masculinity running insanely rampant.

  

[Read Empire's review of Fight Club](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/fight-club-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Making [Arnie'](https://www.empireonline.com/people/arnold-schwarzenegger/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}s T-800 a protector rather than killer for part two could have been a shark-jump moment for the _Terminator_ series, but we're talking about [James Cameron](https://www.empireonline.com/people/james-cameron/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} here. So it paid off — especially as this Terminator was just as much a student in human behaviour (with John Connor his teacher) as guardian, with some darkly comical results ("He'll live"). Is it really better than the original? In terms of scale and sheer, balls-out action spectacle, yes.

  

[Read Empire's review of Terminator 2: Judgment Day](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/terminator-2-judgment-day-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

You've voted it your favourite [Kubrick](https://www.empireonline.com/people/stanley-kubrick/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} movie, which makes sense to us. It is arguably his greatest gift to cinema, an infinitely ambitious vision of a space-faring future whose narrative centres on the most pivotal moment in human evolution since some ape-man first bashed another ape-man with an old bone. Graceful, gorgeous, unwearied by time's passing. Rather like that monolith.

  

[Read Empire's review of 2001: A Space Odyssey](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/2001-space-odyssey-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

What does it take to dethrone [James Cameron](https://www.empireonline.com/people/james-cameron/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}? A blockbuster of behemothic proportions. The weight of expectations on _Endgame_ — the culmination of 11 years of interweaving stories, following up the greatest cinematic cliffhanger since _The Empire Strikes Back_ — was immense, which only makes it more miraculous that the Russo Brothers (and writers [Christopher Markus](https://www.empireonline.com/people/christopher-markus/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} & Stephen McFeeley) delivered a thrilling, adventurous, emotional time-travelling trip through the entire MCU so far. The character pay-offs are just as staggering as the action — and when Steve Rogers finally proved worthy enough to lift Mjolnir, a stone-cold cultural moment was created.

  

[Read Empire's review of Avengers: Endgame](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/avengers-endgame-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

On the one hand, re-watching [Ridley Scott'](https://www.empireonline.com/people/ridley-scott/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}s deep-space monster-slasher (and it's a movie which can handle as many re-watches as you can throw at it) makes you appreciate why he keeps coming back to that universe: it's so intoxicatingly atmospheric and deeply compelling, it sticks to you like a parasite. On the other hand, it really does make you wonder why he feels the need to keep tinkering with new cuts. After all, he got it perfectly right the first time around.

  

[Read Empire's review of Alien](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/alien-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

How two sibling indie film-makers with only a slick, sexy little crime film to their name (_Bound_) created their own blockbuster sci-fi franchise. And opened up western audiences to the truth that kung-fu acrobatics are so much more fun than watching American or European muscle-men waving guns around. While also making everyone examine some fundamental philosophical questions about reality. Thanks to the Wachowskis, we all took the red pill, and we've never regretted it.

  

[Read Empire's review of The Matrix](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/matrix-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Will [Christopher Nolan](https://www.empireonline.com/people/christopher-nolan/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} ever make a Bond movie? Well, with Inception he kind of already has. Except, instead of a British secret agent, we get a freelance corporate dream-thief. And the big climactic action sequence is so huge it takes up almost half the movie and is actually three big action sequences temporally nested inside each other around a surreal, metaphysical-conflict core.

  

[Read Empire's review of Inception](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/inception-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Few award ceremony moments stick in the mind more than _Parasite_ taking the Best Picture gong at the Oscars in 2020. It's no surprise that it made history as the first non-English language movie to do so – this South Korean genre-defying delight offers some of the biggest twists and expertly mounted tension in recent memory, with a family of excellent performances from [Song Kang-ho](https://www.empireonline.com/people/song-kang-ho/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}, Park So-dam, Choi Woo-shik and more. Bitingly satirical, darkly comedic and made with unmatched precision, _Parasite_ doesn't just overcome the 'one inch barrier' of subtitles, as referenced in director [Bong Joon-ho](https://www.empireonline.com/people/bong-joon-ho/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s acceptance speech – it obliterates it entirely.

  
[Read Empire's review of Parasite](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/parasite/)

The genius of [James Cameron](https://www.empireonline.com/people/james-cameron/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s self-penned _Alien_ follow-up was to not try to top the original as one of the greatest ever horror movies. Instead, he transplanted the Alien (and, significantly, Ripley) to a different genre, and created one of the greatest ever action movies. That's also a Vietnam metaphor. And also one of the most enduringly quotable films.

  

[Read Empire's review of Aliens](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/aliens-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Rain-lashed, noodle-bar-packed streets shrouded in perpetual night, with giant adverts and neon signs doing the job you'd usually expect of the sun itself... The not-too-distant future had never looked cooler than in [Ridley Scott](https://www.empireonline.com/people/ridley-scott/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s sci-fi gumshoe noir, and we're not sure it ever will.

  

[Read Empire's review of Blade Runner](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/blade-runner-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

When dinosaurs first ruled the movie-Earth, they did so in a herky-jerky stop-motion manner that while charmingly effective, required a fair dose of disbelief-suspension. When [Steven Spielberg](https://www.empireonline.com/people/steven-spielberg/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} brought them back on Isla Nublar, we felt for the first time they could be real, breathing animals (as opposed to monsters). And that's as much thanks to [Stan Winston](https://www.empireonline.com/people/stan-winston/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s astonishing animatronics work as to ILM's groundbreaking CGI.

  

[Read Empire's review of Jurassic Park](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/jurassic-park-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Often cited as the greatest-ever sequel, _TGPII_, as no-one's ever called it, is more accurately described as a seprequel. In a narrative masterstroke, it parallels Michael's ([Al Pacino](https://www.empireonline.com/people/al-pacino/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}) consolidation of power with the ascendance of his Dad, Vito ([Robert De Niro](https://www.empireonline.com/people/robert-de-niro/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}); the triumph of one paving the way to the utter corruption of the other.

  

[Read Empire's review of The Godfather Part II](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/godfather-part-ii-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Part science-fiction caper, part generational culture-clash movie, part weirdo family drama (in which the hero has to rescue his own existence after his mother falls in lust with him, eww), _Back To The Future_ still manages to be timeless despite being so rooted in, well, time. And it might just have the best title of anything on this entire list.

  

[Read Empire's review of Back To The Future](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/back-future-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

In which old dog [George Miller](https://www.empireonline.com/people/george-miller/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} taught Hollywood some new tricks. Stripping the chase movie down to its raw essentials (the plot is basically: run away... then run back again!), Miller expertly built the narrative through some of the most astonishing and gloriously operatic action scenes we'd seen in yonks. While also ensuring his female characters are the film's strongest; [Charlize Theron](https://www.empireonline.com/people/charlize-theron/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s Furiosa and Immortan Joe's ex-brides are inheriting a world "killed" by men...[Read Empire's review of Mad Max: Fury Road](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/mad-max-fury-road-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

[George Lucas](https://www.empireonline.com/people/george-lucas/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}' cocktail of fantasy, sci-fi, Western and World War II movie remains as culturally pervasive as ever. It's so mythically potent, you sense in time it could become a bona-fide religion...

  

[Read Empire's review of Star Wars](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/star-wars-episode-iv-new-hope-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Where [Coppola](https://www.empireonline.com/people/francis-ford-coppola/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} embroiled us in the politics of the Mafia elite, [Martin Scorsese](https://www.empireonline.com/people/martin-scorsese/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} drew us into the treacherous but seductive world of the Mob's foot soldiers. And its honesty was as impactful as its sudden outbursts of (usually [Joe Pesci](https://www.empireonline.com/people/joe-pesci/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}-instigated) violence. Not merely via Henry Hill's ([Ray Liotta](https://www.empireonline.com/people/ray-liotta/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}) narrative, but also Karen's (Lorraine Bracco) perspective: when Henry gives her a gun to hide, she admits, "It turned me on."

  

[Read Empire's review of Goodfellas](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/goodfellas-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

In '81, it must have sounded like the ultimate pitch: the creator of _Star Wars_ teams up with the director of _Jaws_ to make a rip-roaring, Bond-style adventure starring the guy who played Han Solo, in which the bad guys are the evillest ever (the Nazis) and the MacGuffin is a big, gold box which unleashes the power of God. It still sounds like the ultimate pitch.

  

[Read Empire's review of Raiders Of The Lost Ark](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/raiders-lost-ark-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

It was the biggest crossover event in cinematic history, and the biggest cliffhanger we never saw coming. After ten years and eighteen movies, Marvel took superhero filmmaking to a new level when they united all of Earth's mightiest heroes (and several more) against The Mad Titan himself – and incredibly, devastatingly, they lost. _Infinity War_ crashed much-loved characters into each other's orbits, flitting between planets at breakneck speed as the Avengers desperately tried to stop Thanos from clicking his fingers and wiping out half the universe. Spectacular action, punch-the-air moments and big-scale battles are perfectly balanced, as all things should be, with hilarious interplays and aching emotion. Cinema doesn't get much bigger, or better, than this.

  

[Read Empire's review of Avengers: Infinity War](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/avengers-infinity-war-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

If _Reservoir Dogs_ was a blood-spattered calling card, _Pulp Fiction_ saw [Quentin Tarantino](https://www.empireonline.com/people/quentin-tarantino/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer} kick our front door off its hinges — and then get applauded for doing it with such goddamn panache. It wore its numerous influences on its sleeve and yet felt utterly, invigoratingly fresh and new. We happy? Yeah, we happy.

  

[Read Empire's review of Pulp Fiction](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/pulp-fiction-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

Forty-five years young, and [Spielberg](https://www.empireonline.com/people/steven-spielberg/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s breakthrough remains the touchstone for event-movie cinema. Not that any studio these days would dare put out a summer blockbuster that's half monster-on-the-rampage disaster, half guys-bonding-on-a-fishing-trip adventure. Maybe that's why it's never been rebooted. Or just because it's genuinely unsurpassable.

  

[Read Empire's review of Jaws](https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/jaws-review/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}

The warm, leathery embrace of [Morgan Freeman](https://www.empireonline.com/people/morgan-freeman/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}'s narration... The reassuringly [Gary Cooper](https://www.empireonline.com/people/gary-cooper/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}-ish rumple of [Tim Robbins](https://www.empireonline.com/people/tim-robbins/){:target=_blank :rel=noopener noreferrer}' face... Odd that a movie which features such harshness and tragedy should remain a feel-good perennial — even odder when you consider it was a box-office flop on release.
